awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Effective Labeled Data Generation via Generative Adversarial Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent successes in applying deep learning to solve many challenging data science problems is in part due to the availability of large-scale labeled training data. However, creating large-scale labeled datasets is time consuming, labor-intensive, costly, and often requires significant domain knowledge. Many real-world applications, therefore, come with only data with limited label information (i.e., a small amount of labeled data or no labeled data). Thus, lack of labeled training data is still one of major roadblocks in applying deep learning techniques to challenging data science problems. On the other hand, recent advancements in generative adversarial learning have shown promising results in generating realistic data, which could enable a new perspective for alleviating the problem of lacking labeled training data. Thus, this project explores effective labeled data generation via generative adversarial learning. The proposed research extends the state-of-the-art labeled data generation and generative adversarial learning to a new frontier, investigates original problems that entreat innovative solutions and paves the way for a new research endeavor effectively tame synthetic labeled data generation. As many real-world problems face the challenge of limited labeled data, the project has potential to benefit many real-world applications from various disciplines such as Computer Science, Education, Politics, Healthcare and Bioinformatics.

This project proposes novel approaches based on generative adversarial learning for effective labeled data generation to facilitate deep learning with limited label information, investigates associated fundamental research issues and develops effective algorithms. It has three primary research objectives. First, when a small amount of labeled data is available, it explores to estimate the underlying data distribution from unlabeled data and incorporate the label information for labeled data generation, including extremely imbalanced data and incomplete label scenarios. Second, when labeled data is not available, it adopts an alternative weak supervision (e.g., inaccurate labels, inexact labels and pairwise constraints) for generating labeled data. Third, when neither labeled data nor weak supervision is available, it explores to integrate human involvement to generative adversarial learning for providing supervision. Disparate means are planned to disseminate the project and its findings, such as web enabled data and software repositories, books, journal and conference publications, special purpose workshops or tutorials, and industrial collaborations. The project can be effectively integrated to undergraduate and graduate courses as well as in student research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Though deep learning models have shown great performance in many data science problems, training deep learning models generally require large-scale labeled data. However, constructing large-scale labeled datasets is time consuming, labor-intensive, costly, and often requires significant domain knowledge. Many real-world applications, therefore, come with only data with limited label information (i.e., a small amount of labeled data or no labeled data). Thus, lack of labeled training data is still one of major roadblocks in applying deep learning techniques to challenging data science problems. On the other hand, recent advancements in generative adversarial learning have shown promising results in generating realistic data, which could enable a new perspective for alleviating the problem of lacking labeled training data. Therefore, this project proposes novel approaches based on generative adversarial learning for effective labeled data generation to facilitate deep learning with limited label information, investigates associated fundamental research issues and develops effective algorithms. It has three primary research objectives.

 

First, when a small amount of labeled data is available, this project explores to estimate the underlying data distribution from unlabeled data and incorporate the label information for labeled data generation, including extremely imbalanced data and incomplete label scenarios: (i) In our paper published in SDM 2020, we studied a novel problem of labeled data generation for imbalanced data. We proposed a novel framework GL-GAN, which leverages the synthetic minority over sampling (SMOTE) and generative adversarial network (GAN) to generate high-quality synthetic minority samples even extremely imbalanced scenarios. Experimental results on diverse real data sets demonstrate the effectiveness of our GL-GAN framework in producing realistic and discriminative minority samples for improving the classification performance of various classifiers on imbalanced training data; (ii) In our WSDM 2021 paper, we developed a novel framework GraphSMOTE to tackle imbalanced node classification problem. We propose a framework which can generate synthetic minority nodes and connect the nodes to existing graphs to facilitate node classification with graph neural networks. It achieved state-of-the-art performance; (iii) In our ICDM-2020 paper, we studied a novel problem of labeled data generation under positive and unlabeled scenario, where only a part of labels of one category is known while the rest are unknown. We propose a novel generative framework LILA, which can produce synthetic labeled samples for both partially labeled categories and unlabeled categories.

 

Second, when labeled data is not available, it adopts an alternative weak supervision (e.g., inaccurate labels, inexact labels and pairwise constraints) for generating labeled data: (i) In our paper published in KDD 2021, we study a novel problem of labeled data generation with inexact supervision, e.g., for the training data, we only have supervision/tags related to the target classes. We propose a novel generative framework named as ADDES which can synthesize high-quality labeled data for target classification tasks by learning from data with inexact supervision and the relations between inexact supervision and target classes. Experimental results on image and text datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ADDES for generating realistic labeled data from inexact supervision to facilitate the target classification task. (ii) In another paper published in KDD 2021, we proposed a novel label-noise resistant graph neural networks (NRGNN) on sparsely and noisily labeled graphs. Our theoretical and empirical analysis verify the effectiveness of the proposed strategies under mild conditions. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NRGNN in learning a robust GNN with noisy and limited labels.

 

Third, when neither labeled data nor weak supervision is available, it explores to integrate human involvement to generative adversarial learning for providing supervision. For example, in our paper published in WWW 2022, we developed a framework ALLIE for active learning on large-scale imbalanced graphs. In a paper published in SDM 2024, we developed a robust active learning framework GALClean, which can conduct robust node classification on noisy graphs.

 

In addition, we also explored labeled data generation for trustworthy machine learning models. For example, in a paper published in KDD 2020, we developed a novel adversarial generative framework GRACE to generate concise and Informative contrastive sample to explain neural network model's prediction. In a paper published in ICDM 2020, we developed a novel framework MALCOM, which can generate malicious comments to attack neural fake news detection model.

 

The project has resulted in more than 50 papers in top-tier journals and conferences on machine learning and data mining, trained seven PhD students and two undergraduate students. Three of the PhD students have graduated partially supported by the project. The findings are also integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the PIs such as DS 310 Machine Learning and Data Analytics and DS 305 Algorithmic Methods and Tools. Publications and software resulted from this project are disseminated on this website: https://faculty.ist.psu.edu/szw494/projects/labeled_data_generation.html.
